title: four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_2
question_with_options:
**Question:** What cultural phenomenon does the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_2" reference?

A) The concept of racial genetic traits  
B) The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse from the Christian Bible  
C) Popular animated characters  
D) The concept of chaos in modern memes
reasoning: The meme in question directly references the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse," which is explained in Document 0. This document describes the cultural significance and origin of the Four Horsemen, noting how they have been parodied online. The other document (Document 1) discusses a completely unrelated topic about racial genetic traits, making it a distractor. The images in the meme likely depict characters that humorously represent the Four Horsemen, aligning with the information in Document 0. Therefore, the correct answer is B, as it is the only option that accurately reflects the cultural phenomenon referenced in the meme.
oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

**Question:** What cultural commentary does the meme "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" make about social roles or stereotypes?

A) It highlights the seriousness of end-of-the-world scenarios.

B) It parodies the concept of significant figures in a humorous way.

C) It addresses the complexities of racial identity.

D) It promotes traditional gender roles in society.
reasoning: The meme portrays a humorous take on the traditional concept of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse by using individuals dressed in silly costumes, thereby mocking the seriousness usually associated with these figures. This aligns with the information in Document 0, which discusses how the Four Horsemen are often parodied in a lighthearted manner. Document 1, on the other hand, focuses on racial identity and is not relevant to understanding the humor or cultural commentary present in this meme. Thus, the correct option is B, as it best captures the essence of the meme's intent to parody significant figures in a comical way.
oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

Document 0 provides the necessary background on the Four Horsemen and their traditional representations, confirming the situational irony. Document 1 is not relevant here as it discusses a different meme context.

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 8]

caption: a collage of photos of a woman in a costume

A) Consumerism leading to environmental collapse  
B) Racial stereotypes in media portrayals  
C) Social roles in entertainment  
D) The absurdity of societal norms
reasoning: The meme depicts four characters humorously personifying the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse," each represented by everyday objects or roles. This parody highlights the absurdity and trivialization of serious themes, such as the apocalypse, suggesting a commentary on societal norms and the mundane aspects of life. Document 0 provides context about the Four Horsemen and their representation in memes, which supports the idea that this meme reflects societal norms. Document 1, while discussing racial stereotypes, does not relate to the meme's focus on absurdity and societal commentary. Thus, the best option that captures the essence of the meme is D, as it highlights the ridiculousness of the depicted roles in contrast to the serious theme of apocalypse.

oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The fictional 'Ethnic Expression Scale' memes categorize individuals into made-up 'expression types' based on their racial background, falsely claiming certain races are inherently more expressive. [Document ID: 7]

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

caption: a collage of photos of a woman in a suit

title: four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_4
question_with_options:
**Question:** In the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_4," what does the collage of photos of a woman in a suit symbolize in relation to the concept of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse?

A) The emergence of new leaders in a time of crisis  
B) The inevitability of societal collapse  
C) The blending of professional and apocalyptic themes  
D) The role of women in historical conflicts
reasoning: To analyze the symbolism in the meme, we can refer to Document 1, which discusses the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, representing Conquest, War, Famine, and Death—figures associated with the end times. The image of a woman in a suit could symbolize a new kind of leader or authority during a crisis, which aligns with option A. However, the humor in the meme suggests a blending of serious themes (apocalypse) with everyday life (professional settings), which relates closely to option C. The other options (B and D) do not directly connect as clearly to the context of the meme as they lean more towards interpretations that may not encapsulate the lighthearted nature and metaphorical play inherent in meme culture. Ultimately, the correct answer focuses on the juxtaposition of traditional apocalyptic themes with modern professional identity. Therefore, option C is the most fitting interpretation.

**Question:** How does the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_4" relate to power dynamics or social status?

A) It humorously critiques the idea of authority by associating serious figures with mundane or ridiculous images.  
B) It suggests that all individuals portrayed in the collage hold equal power and status.  
C) It reinforces traditional roles by depicting the woman in a suit as a powerful figure among the four horsemen.  
D) It illustrates the concept of the 'Triple Heritage Theory' by combining cultural elements from different ethnic groups.
reasoning: To analyze how the meme relates to power dynamics or social status, we focus on the image caption, which describes a collage of photos of a woman in a suit. This can imply a powerful or authoritative figure, especially in contrast to the concept of the Four Horsemen, who are traditionally associated with significant power in a biblical context. Option A is relevant because it suggests a critique of authority, aligning with the humorous tone of memes. Option C also connects, as it highlights the woman’s status as a powerful figure, which could be interpreted as a commentary on gender roles in power dynamics. oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 2]

four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: 'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 8]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

caption: a collage of photos of a man and a woman

title: four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_6
question_with_options:
**Question:** How does the meaning of the meme change when the text is viewed without the accompanying images?

A) The text alone reinforces the biblical origins of the Four Horsemen.  
B) The text loses its humorous context without the images.  
C) The text provides a deeper understanding of the characters' roles.  
D) The text becomes irrelevant without the images.
reasoning: The meme uses visual elements to create a humorous contrast between the serious depiction of the Four Horsemen in biblical art and a more mundane interpretation suggested by the text. Document 1 discusses the Four Horsemen as characters often parodied in memes, which aligns with the humor in the meme's caption. Without the images, the humor and contextual contrast would be lost, making option B the most accurate. The other options do not correctly capture the essence of the shift in meaning when the text is isolated.

A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread

For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). question_with_options:
Question: What kind of irony is revealed in the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_8"?

A) Verbal irony, where the words used imply a meaning that is different from the literal meaning.  
B) Situational irony, where the outcome is incongruent with what was expected.  
C) Dramatic irony, where the audience knows something that the characters do not.  
D) Cosmic irony, where fate toys with human hopes and expectations.
reasoning:
To analyze the meme "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_8" and determine the type of irony, we can refer to Document ID 1, which explains the cultural context of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. This document describes how the Four Horsemen are typically associated with serious and catastrophic themes such as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death, which typically invoke a sense of dread and seriousness. 

However, the caption indicates a collage of people in the woods, which could imply a lighthearted or contrasting scenario when juxtaposed with the concept of the Four Horsemen, suggesting an unexpected and incongruous outcome. This aligns with situational irony, where the meme portrays a serious concept in a trivial or absurd context, contrasting the expected grimness of the Horsemen with a casual or humorous depiction of people in the woods.

Options A, C, and D do not fit the context as they relate to different forms of irony that do not capture the unexpected nature of the meme's imagery. Thus, the correct answer is B) Situational irony.

The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

A) It directly mocks the biblical concept of the Four Horsemen by replacing them with modern characters.  
B) It compares a traditional painting style to modern meme culture, highlighting absurdity.  
C) It suggests that the woman represents War, implying that women can be warriors too.  
D) It trivializes serious themes of the apocalypse by presenting them in a humorous context.
reasoning: To analyze how this meme incorporates satirical elements, we look at the relevant document, which discusses the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" and their cultural representations. The meme title suggests a humorous take on a serious biblical concept by juxtaposing a painting of a woman and a horse with the idea of the Four Horsemen, which traditionally symbolize doom and destruction. The document illustrates how the Four Horsemen are often parodied online, which aligns with option D, as it points out the trivialization of serious themes. Options A and C are less relevant since they focus on specific interpretations of characters rather than the overall satirical context, and option B, while touching on modern meme culture, does not directly address the satire element as effectively as D does. Therefore, D is the most accurate answer.
oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: 'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 5]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

caption: a painting of a woman and a horse

title: four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_9
question_with_options:
**Question:** What message is conveyed through the combination of the image and text in the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_9"?

A) The image humorously depicts actual demographic changes.  
B) The image represents the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse in a modern context.  
C) The image promotes a peaceful coexistence among different groups.  
D) The image illustrates the consequences of climate change.
reasoning: The image shows four distinct characters associated with horses, aligning with the biblical concept of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, which is discussed in Document 0. This document explains the origins and interpretations of the Four Horsemen in a modern meme context, highlighting their role as harbingers of significant change or destruction. The other documents, particularly Document 1, discussing manipulated statistics, are not relevant to the interpretation of this meme, as they do not address the imagery or its connection to the Four Horsemen. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question_with_options:
**Question:** What potential counterarguments exist to the perspective shown in the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" meme?

A) The Four Horsemen are simply fictional characters with no real-world implications.

B) The meme trivializes serious themes by using humor, making it less impactful.

C) The interpretations of the Four Horsemen can vary widely among different cultures and religions.

D) The visual representation in the meme might not accurately reflect the original biblical descriptions.
reasoning:
To determine the best counterarguments against the perspective of the meme, we can draw from Document ID 1, which explains the origins and interpretations of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. Option A suggests that the characters are fictional, which counters any arguments that treat them as real entities. Option B points out that the use of humor can diminish the seriousness of the subject matter, which is relevant to the meme's comedic aspect. Option C highlights the varying interpretations across cultures, which is a valid counter to a singular perspective. Option D discusses potential inaccuracies in visual representation, emphasizing that memes often adapt or alter original concepts. 

While all options present valid points, option C stands out as it addresses the cultural and religious diversity of interpretation, which directly counters a singular view. 

Thus, the most comprehensive counterargument is that interpretations can vary widely.

oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

title: four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_11
question_with_options:
**Question:** What is the primary theme of the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_11" when considering the context of the image caption, "a man in a suit is holding a video game controller"?

A) The man represents one of the Four Horsemen bringing about the end of video games.  
B) The meme humorously suggests that video games are a serious threat to society.  
C) The man symbolizes the modern-day consequences of gaming culture in a professional setting.  
D) The image and caption together imply that video games are a new apocalypse.
reasoning: To analyze this meme, we refer to the relevant sections in Document 1, which explains the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse concept and its application in online meme culture. The image caption describes a man in a suit with a video game controller, implying a juxtaposition of seriousness (the suit) with a casual activity (gaming). This can be interpreted as a commentary on how gaming is perceived in serious contexts, aligning with option C. While option D could also seem relevant, it lacks the nuance of the man representing modern consequences, which is more directly supported by the context of the document. Therefore, the best choice is C.

Therefore, the strongest interpretation is that the meme conveys the serious nature of conflict, particularly through its depiction of war, despite the humorous undertones of the video game reference. Thus, option B is the most relevant answer.

Question: What underlying assumption does the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_11," featuring a man in a suit holding a video game controller, imply about the relationship between authority and technology?

A) Authority figures are always opposed to technology.  
B) Technology is a tool for entertainment that distracts from serious issues.  
C) Authority figures are depicted as incompetent when using technology.  
D) The meme conveys a message that technology will lead to the apocalypse.
reasoning: The meme title "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_11" suggests a humorous take on serious themes like authority and technology. The image caption indicates that a man in a suit, typically representing authority, is engaged with a video game controller, which might imply a disconnect or a trivialization of serious matters in favor of entertainment. This aligns with option B, which states that technology serves as a distraction from serious issues. Document 0 discusses the Four Horsemen and their representation in memes, emphasizing the humor and satire aspects, which supports B. Document 1 discusses fabricated statistics on immigrant assimilation, which is not relevant to this meme, making it a distractor. Therefore, the most appropriate underlying assumption that the meme implies is that technology is a tool for entertainment that distracts from serious issues.

**Question:** What underlying assumptions about conflict and societal issues are present in the meme titled "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse_11"?

A) It promotes the idea that video games cause violence in society.  
B) It trivializes the concept of war by depicting it through a gaming lens.  
C) It suggests that the Four Horsemen are merely fictional characters without real-world implications.  
D) It highlights the inevitability of societal destruction through conflict.
reasoning: To analyze the meme, we can reference the context provided in Document 0, which discusses the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse in a biblical context and their representation of serious themes such as war and destruction. The meme's depiction of a man in a suit holding a video game controller can be interpreted as a commentary on how modern society engages with themes of war and conflict in a trivial manner, suggesting a disconnect between real violence and its portrayal in gaming culture. Thus, option B is the most relevant as it captures the essence of trivialization present in the meme. Options A and D do not align closely with the meme's portrayal, while option C dismisses the thematic implications entirely. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

A) It illustrates how different roles in society contribute to a chaotic environment.  
B) It reflects the serious nature of societal issues without any humor.  
C) It ranks countries based on fictional metrics of racial integration.  
D) It emphasizes the importance of individual decision-making in societal conflict.
reasoning: The relevant document for this analysis is the first one, which discusses the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" as a parody in memes, showing how various characters are labeled to humorously represent concepts of chaos and conflict linked to power dynamics. The meme itself captures the indecision and diverse roles people play in societal strife. In contrast, the second document relates to a different topic—fictional metrics of racial integration—which does not pertain to the dynamics illustrated in the meme. Therefore, option A is correct as it encapsulates the essence of the meme's commentary on societal roles and chaos.
oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

question_with_options:
**Question:** How does the "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse" meme reflect on contemporary social conflicts regarding power dynamics or social status?

A) It highlights the absurdity of serious issues by trivializing them with humor.  
B) It represents the inevitability of social change and the collapse of established power structures.  
C) It showcases how individuals in power can become caricatures, emphasizing their roles in societal conflicts.  
D) It reinforces existing stereotypes about authority figures in society.
reasoning: The "four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse" meme relates closely to power dynamics as it uses the symbolism of the Four Horsemen, who traditionally bring about chaos and conflict, to comment on contemporary figures in positions of power. The document about the Four Horsemen suggests that these figures are often portrayed humorously, reducing their serious implications and highlighting their conflicts. Option C is particularly relevant here, as it indicates that the meme can serve to critique or satirize authority figures by representing them as exaggerated characters that embody societal conflicts. Thus, the most appropriate answer is C, as it directly connects to how the meme uses humor to discuss and reflect on social status and conflict. Options A, B, and D either misinterpret the intent of the meme or do not directly address the critique of power dynamics as effectively as C does.

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

caption: a collage of photos of a man in a suit

The oracle document (0) discusses the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse and their representation of significant societal problems, but does not directly mention corporate themes. However, the imagery of a man in a suit is commonly associated with corporate or capitalist critiques, which aligns with option B (Corporate greed). 

The other options (A, C, D) do not have strong connections to the imagery or themes presented in the meme. Document 1 mentions a different meme format related to racial stereotypes, but it does not relate to the Four Horsemen or the specific imagery of the meme in question. Therefore, the most relevant critique represented in the meme is centered on corporate greed. 

Thus, the correct answer is B.

The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: Viral 'Face-Swap' race memes peaked in 2020, incorrectly suggesting that facial recognition AI can't distinguish between individuals of certain racial groups, which was disproven by multiple studies. [Document ID: 4]
